content: DEPARTMENTAL REORGANIZATION. The Homeland Security Act of 2002 is amended to redesignate the Directorate for Information Analysis and Infrastructure Protection to an Office of Intelligence and Analysis, with corresponding changes to the Under Secretary position. Subsections are also reorganized within the Act. The Homeland Security Act of 2002 is amended to rename the Directorate for Information Analysis and Infrastructure Protection to the Office of Intelligence and Analysis. Subsections within the Act are also reorganized, with changes to the Under Secretary position. The Homeland Security Act of 2002 is amended to rename the Directorate for Information Analysis and Infrastructure Protection to the Office of Intelligence and Analysis. The reorganization includes changes to the Under Secretary position and the addition of new paragraphs to enhance integration among intelligence components, establish intelligence priorities, policies, and procedures for the Department. The Office of Intelligence and Analysis within the Department of Homeland Security is tasked with supporting intelligence components, producing unclassified reports based on open-source information, and ensuring timely dissemination of information. The Office of Intelligence Analysis in the Department of Homeland Security must establish an Internal Continuity of Operations Plan to ensure uninterrupted operations during various emergencies, including natural disasters, accidents, and attacks. This plan includes succession procedures and emergency delegations of authority. The Office of Intelligence Analysis in the Department of Homeland Security must establish an Internal Continuity of Operations Plan to ensure uninterrupted operations during emergencies, including the safekeeping of vital resources, facilities, and records, emergency acquisition of resources, and relocation of personnel to alternate work sites. The Homeland Security Act of 2002 is amended to replace "the Under Secretary for Information Analysis and Infrastructure Protection" with "the Under Secretary for Intelligence and Analysis and the Assistant Secretary for Infrastructure Protection" and to include "section 203" under this section. The Homeland Security Act of 2002 is amended to replace the Under Secretary for Information Analysis and Infrastructure Protection with the Under Secretary for Intelligence and Analysis and the Assistant Secretary for Infrastructure Protection in various sections. The Homeland Security Act of 2002 is amended to replace the Directorate for Information Analysis and Infrastructure Protection with the Office of Intelligence and Analysis, and the Under Secretary for Information Analysis and Infrastructure Protection with the Under Secretary for Intelligence and Analysis. Additionally, the second section 510 is redesignated as section 511. The Homeland Security Act of 2002 is amended to establish the Office of Intelligence and Analysis, replacing the Directorate for Information Analysis and Infrastructure Protection. The Under Secretary for Information Analysis and Infrastructure Protection is now the Under Secretary for Intelligence and Analysis. Section 510 is redesignated as section 511. The Homeland Security Act of 2002 is amended to establish the Office of Intelligence and Analysis, replacing the Directorate for Information Analysis and Infrastructure Protection. The Under Secretary for Information Analysis and Infrastructure Protection is now the Under Secretary for Intelligence and Analysis. Amendments are made to section headings in subsections (a) and (b) of section 121, as well as to Section 106(b)(2)(I) of the National Security Act of 1947 and Section 7306(a)(1) of the Intelligence Reform and Terrorism Prevention Act of 2004. The Intelligence Reform and Terrorism Prevention Act of 2004 is amended to change the title of the Under Secretary from "Information Analysis and Infrastructure Protection" to "Intelligence and Analysis". Additionally, a clerical amendment is made to the table of contents in the Homeland Security Act of 2002. SEC. 2 amends the Homeland Security Act of 2002 to include new intelligence components within the Department of Homeland Security. The head of each intelligence component of the Department of Homeland Security is responsible for ensuring effective acquisition, analysis, and dissemination of homeland security information in support of the Under Secretary for Intelligence and Analysis. They must also implement established goals, incorporate input from the Under Secretary for performance evaluations and coordinate in recruitment and selection. The intelligence component is responsible for advising on reorganization, ensuring compliance with policies, and performing other related duties as assigned by the Secretary. Training for employees is also provided by the Secretary. The Secretary provides training and guidance for employees, officials, and senior executives of the intelligence components of the Department to develop knowledge of laws, regulations, operations, policies, procedures, and programs related to homeland security information. The term 'intelligence component of the Department' is defined as any directorate, agency, or element that gathers, receives, analyzes, produces, or disseminates homeland security information. The Secretary provides training and guidance for employees, officials, and senior executives of the intelligence components of the Department to develop knowledge of laws, regulations, operations, policies, procedures, and programs related to homeland security information. This includes maintaining distinct entities and security programs within the Department. The Office of Infrastructure Protection is established under the Homeland Security Act of 2002 to enhance security measures for critical infrastructure. The Office of Infrastructure Protection, established under the Homeland Security Act of 2002, is headed by an Assistant Secretary for Infrastructure Protection. The Assistant Secretary assists the Secretary in carrying out responsibilities related to infrastructure protection, ensuring that the Department's duties in this area are fulfilled. The Assistant Secretary is responsible for conducting assessments of key resources and critical vulnerabilities under the direction of the Secretary. The Office of Infrastructure Protection, established under the Homeland Security Act of 2002, assesses vulnerabilities of key resources and critical infrastructure in the United States. This includes conducting risk assessments for potential terrorist attacks, integrating relevant information to identify protective measures by various government agencies, private sector, and other entities. The Office of Infrastructure Protection, established under the Homeland Security Act of 2002, assesses vulnerabilities of key resources and critical infrastructure in the United States. This includes developing a comprehensive national plan and recommending protective measures in coordination with other federal agencies, state and local government agencies, the private sector, and other entities. The Office of Infrastructure Protection, established under the Homeland Security Act of 2002, coordinates with various entities including the intelligence community, law enforcement agencies, and the private sector. The Secretary provides the office with a staff with appropriate expertise, including staff from the private sector with necessary security clearances. The Office of Infrastructure Protection coordinates with the intelligence community, law enforcement agencies, and the private sector. Personnel from other Federal agencies may be detailed to the Department for analytic functions and related duties on a reimbursable or non-reimbursable basis. The Office of Infrastructure Protection coordinates with various entities and may have personnel detailed from other Federal agencies for analytic functions and related duties.
